Regularizer multiplier Î»ğœ†\lambda.
We perform an analysis of the learning rate multiplier of the softmax regularizer Î»ğœ†\lambda on LFW. As shown in TableÂ 2, FedGC achieves the best performance when Î»ğœ†\lambda is 20. It is shown that a large multiplier also cause network collapsing, as it makes within-client class embeddings collapse to one point. When Î»ğœ†\lambda is very small, then the model degenerates into baseline model FedPE.

Here we constructed a unbalanced partition by logarithmic normal distribution: lnâ¡Xâˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,1)similar-toğ‘‹ğ‘01\ln X\sim N\left(0,1\right). We perform an analysis on the model with softmax loss functions on LFW. In tableÂ 3, it shows that unbalanced partition even improve the performance of network to some extent. We find that the clients which holds larger scale dataset than average contribute significantly to network and make it generate more discriminative representations. And FedGC still outperforms baseline model on both balanced and unbalanced datasets.

references: Cosine v.s. Softmax Regularizer. We replace softmax regularizer with cosine regularizer, namely FedCos: âˆ‘zâ‰ kâˆ‘j=0CzWz,jTâ€‹Wk,isubscriptğ‘§ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0subscriptğ¶ğ‘§superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘§ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Šğ‘˜ğ‘–\sum_{z\neq k}\sum_{j=0}^{C_{z}}W_{z,j}^{T}W_{k,i}, and guided by softmax loss function. We show the verification result on LFW in TableÂ 4. Although cosine regularizer shows a better accuracy than FedPE, it is still worse than FedGC. Because softmax regularizer can be regarded as a hard sample mining version of cosine regularizer, and also match the gradient in standard softmax. Thus, the superiority of softmax regularizer is proved experimentally.

Regularizer v.s. Fixed. It has been proved that random initialized vectors in high dimensional spaces (512 in this case) are almost orthogonal to each other. A naÃ¯ve way to prevent the class embeddings from collapsing into a overlapping space is keep the class embeddings fixed to initialization.
TableÂ 5 shows that proposed FedGC outperforms model with fully-connected layer fixed (â€-Fixedâ€). For softmax loss function, simply fixing the last fully-connected layer leads to a better accuracy. However, for Arcface and Cosface which introduce a more strict constraint, the performance of the model is even worse than baseline model. Intuitively, random initialized orthogonal vectors lack semantic information, and it confuses the network in a more difficult classification task. Thus, it is shown that the performance is further increased with adaptive optimization (FedGC).

LFW, CALFW, CPLFW, CFP-FP, VGG2-FP SLLFW and AgeDB-30.
In this section, we explore the performance of different loss functions (Softmax, Cosface (Wang etÂ al. 2018c), Arcface (Deng etÂ al. 2019)). We set the margin of Cosface (Wang etÂ al. 2018c) at 0.35. For Arcface (Deng etÂ al. 2019), we set the feature scale sğ‘ s to 64 and choose the angular margin mğ‘šm at 0.5. The performance of a model trained with federated learning algorithms is inherently upper bounded by that of model trained in the centralized fashion. TableÂ 5 shows the experiments results, where â€-Xâ€ means the dataset is trained by method â€Xâ€.
FedGC achieves the highest average accuracy for all loss functions (Softmax, Arcface , Cosface) and performs better on all of the above datasets. For ArcFace(m=0.5ğ‘š0.5m=0.5), the centralized method even achieves a poor performance worse than FedPE. And FedGC can also match the performance of conventional centralized methods.

references:
MegaFace. The MegaFace dataset (Kemelmacher-Shlizerman etÂ al. 2016) includes 1M images of 690K different individuals as the gallery set and 100K photos of 530 unique individuals from FaceScrub (Ng and Winkler 2014) as the probe set. It measures TPR at 1e-6 FPR for verification and Rank-1 retrieval performance for identification. In TableÂ 6, adopting FaceScrub as probe set and using the wash list provided by DeepInsight (Deng etÂ al. 2019),
FedGC outperforms the baseline model FedPE by a large margin in different loss functions on both verification and identification tasks. Some centralized methods (Softmax, ArcFace(m=0.5ğ‘š0.5m=0.5)) even show a poor performance when the learning rate is 0.1. It shows that FedGC can match the performance of conventional centralized methods.

IJB-B and IJB-C. The IJB-B dataset (Whitelam etÂ al. 2017) contains 1, 845 subjects with 21.8K still images and 55K
frames from 7, 011 videos. In total, there are 12, 115 templates with 10, 270 genuine matches and 8M impostor matches. The IJB-C dataset (Maze etÂ al. 2018) is a further extension of IJB-B, having 3, 531 subjects with 31.3K still images and 117.5K frames from 11, 779 videos. In total, there are 23, 124 templates with 19, 557 genuine matches and 15, 639K impostor matches. The verification TPR at 1e-3 FPR and identification Rank-1 are reported in TableÂ 7. FedGC shows significant improvements and surpasses all candidates by a large margin. Compared with centralized method on all of three loss functions, FedGC can match the performance of conventional centralized methods on both IJB-B and IJB-C datasets.
